channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Suicide Bomber Targets Afghan Army Vehicle
item.description: Four people were killed, including two civilians, in an attack on a shuttle bus transporting soldiers through Kabul.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: China Sentences Legal Activist to 4 Years for Role in Protests
item.description: Xu Zhiyong campaigned against official corruption and social injustice as part of the New Citizens Movement.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Egyptian Envoys Plead for Release
item.description: Five Egyptian diplomats kidnapped in Tripoli in retaliation for Egypt’s arrest of a Libyan militia chief pleaded on Saturday for their government to free him to secure their release.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Islamist Party to Boycott Algerian Election
item.description: Algeria’s largest Islamist political party announced it will boycott April’s presidential election, citing fears of fraud.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 32 People Feared Dead in Quebec Fire
item.description: Two more bodies were found as search crews struggled in the cold at a retirement home, the site of a fire on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Dismisses Charges Against Soldiers in Killings
item.description: The army dismissed charges against five soldiers in a case from 2000 in which soldiers were accused of rounding up five Kashmiri men, then shooting and burning them.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Mortar Bombs Kill Six in Shiite Village in Iraq
item.description: In the deadliest attack of several across the nation, three mortar bombs killed six people in a village near Baquba, 40 miles northeast of Baghdad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Nepal Lawmakers Move Closer to Choosing a Prime Minister
item.description: The country’s Supreme Court dismissed calls for an immediate election and allowed President Ram Baran Yadav to remain in office for now.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Emirates President Treated for Stroke
item.description: The state news agency said that Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed al-Nahyan was in stable condition and had undergone surgery.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Holocaust Told in One Word, 6 Million Times
item.description: The book “And Every Single One Was Someone” — meant as a kind of coffee-table monument or conversation starter — consists of the single word “Jew,” printed six million times.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: More art than literature, the new book “And Every Single One Was Someone” consists only of the word “Jew,” repeated.

item.title: Philippines and Rebels Agree on Peace Accord to End Insurgency
item.description: The agreement will create an autonomous Muslim-dominated region in the restive south of the predominantly Christian country.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: The government negotiator, left, shaking hands with the representative of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front on Saturday.

item.title: House Republicans to Offer Broad Immigration Plan
item.description: The plan is expected to call for border security and enforcement measures, as well as providing a path to legal status — but not citizenship — for many undocumented immigrants.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY PARKER and JONATHAN WEISMAN

item.title: Opposition Says No to Ukraine on Power Share
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovych offered to install opposition leaders in top government posts, but they swiftly rebuffed the offer, to the delight of thousands of protesters on the street.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters lit tires aflame during clashes with riot police in Kiev. It was unclear if they would accept the president’s concessions.

item.title: France’s President Announces Split With His Companion
item.description: President François Hollande announced Saturday that he and Valérie Trierweiler, who had served as France’s de facto first lady, had separated.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: François Hollande announced Saturday that he and Valérie Trierweiler had separated.

item.title: Beijing’s Bad Air Would Be Step Up for Smoggy Delhi
item.description: Researchers suspect that India’s unusual mix of polluted air, poor sanitation and contaminated water may make the country among the most dangerous in the world for lungs.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Sami Siva for The New York Times
item.media:description: People made a fire in New Delhi to keep warm on Friday, one of many sources of pollution that makes the city’s air among the world’s worst.

item.title: Syria’s Shaky Peace Talks Move Toward Solid Ground in Effort to Aid Homs
item.description: The Syrian government and opposition met face to face in Geneva for the first time to try to win government approval for an aid convoy to parts of Homs.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Clashes Kill 49 Egyptians on Uprising’s Anniversary
item.description: At least 49 people died in clashes with security forces at rival antigovernment protests organized by Islamists and left-leaning activists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: False Claims in Afghan Accusations on U.S. Raid Add to Doubts on Karzai
item.description: The government of President Hamid Karzai handed out an inflammatory dossier about airstrikes on Jan. 15 on a remote village and the supposed American cover-up that followed.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: An image of a funeral in Afghanistan that the government tied to a recent American airstrike actually took place in 2009.

item.title: The Lede: Scarlett Johansson’s SodaStream Endorsement Deal Conflicts With Charity Work, Aid Group Says
item.description: Oxfam has distanced itself from one of its global ambassadors, Scarlett Johansson, since she agreed to become the face of SodaStream, an Israeli firm that makes products in a settlement in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: China Accuses Uighur Intellectual of Separatism for His Advocacy Work
item.description: A statement from security officials in the Xinjiang region accused Ilham Tohti, an economics professor who advocates on behalf of Uighurs, of separatism and inciting ethnic hatred.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: News Analysis: The Franchising of Al Qaeda
item.description: Without Bin Laden, the terrorist group is no longer cohesive, with a clear purpose.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Members of the Syrian rebel group Ahrar al-Sham at a training camp in a Damascus suburb, in early December.

item.title: DealBook: Geopolitical Tensions Fly During Panel on American Interests
item.description: Syria, the Iraq war and other trouble spots were hot-button issues in a panel that included Senator John McCain, the Republican from Arizona, and Aleksei K. Pushkov, the head of Russia’s parliamentary Foreign Affairs Committee.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED
item.media:description: Senator John McCain at a session on Friday at the World Economic Forum.

item.title: DealBook: Economic Shifts in U.S. and China Batter Markets
item.description: With China’s rise and the Federal Reserve’s economic action both in retreat, investors have been heading for the exits in markets as far removed as Buenos Aires, Istanbul and Beijing, with effects spilling over into the rest of the world.
item.dc:creator: By NATHANIEL POPPER
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange on Friday, where the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index ended its worst week since June 2012.

item.title: Clashes in China’s Restive Region Kill 12
item.description: Chinese state media say six people have died in explosions and another six were shot dead by police in fresh violence in the far west region of Xinjiang.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Filmmaker Who Mocks Authorities on YouTube Detained Amid Widening Crackdown in Cairo
item.description: The sense that Egypt’s revolution has come full circle intensified with the arrest of an artist who posts wry commentaries on the country’s leaders on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
